review.title: Diving Deep into Clickbaits: Who Use Them to What Extents in Which Topics with What Effects?
review.abstract: The use of alluring headlines (clickbait) to tempt the readers has become a growing practice nowadays. For the sake of existence in the highly competitive media industry, most of the on-line media including the mainstream ones, have started following this practice. Although the wide-spread practice of clickbait makes the reader's reliability on media vulnerable, a large scale analysis to reveal this fact is still absent. In this paper, we analyze 1.67 million Facebook posts created by 153 media organizations to understand the extent of clickbait practice, its impact and user engagement by using our own developed clickbait detection model. The model uses distributed sub-word embeddings learned from a large corpus. The accuracy of the model is 98.3%. Powered with this model, we further study the distribution of topics in clickbait and non-clickbait contents.

[3] Taboola, one of the major providers of clickbait content, claims to have doubled its monthly reach from 500 million users to $1 billion. [4] The growth of the clickbait industry appears to have a clear impact on the media system, as many traditional media companies have begun to use clickbait methods to attract readers and generate revenue. However, media analysts point out that news media outlets risk losing readers by using clickbait techniques that can only temporarily increase advertising revenue.

sections.heading: IV. PRACTICE OF USING CLICKBAIT IN SOCIAL NETWORK
sections.text: We analyze click bait practices at Facebook using the Media Corpus from three perspectives.

sections.heading: A. Quantitative Analysis
sections.text: In order to understand the extent of clickbait practice by different media and their categories, we applied the clickbait recognition model to their content; in particular, to the headline / title of the link / video art posts. From now on, we will use the term headline to denote both the headline of a link content (article) and the title of a video content. Table III shows amounts of clickbait and non-clickbait in the headlines of the mainstream media and unreliable media. Of 887, 794 mainstream media posts, 297, 774 (33.54%) have clickbait headlines. In unreliable media, the ratio is 39.26% (308, 095 clickbait headlines of 784, 665). Based on these statistics, the percentage for the mainstream media appears surprisingly high. We zoom into the categories of these two media to analyze the primary advocates of clickbait practice.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we present a word embedding-based clickbait recognition system that builds on our own aggregated body of news headlines and content; we have shown that our model performs better than embedding Google news records; our analysis also shows how mainstream media is increasingly being incorporated into clickbait practice; a closer examination of social media posts also shows that media work with a higher percentage of clickbait practice than print and non-news media; our study brings to light another fact, namely the use of a higher percentage of clickbait practice by unreliable media, which is fairly obvious; and we believe that the results of our topic modeling suggest that clickbait practice is prevalent in personalized and entertaining areas; and that in the future, we want to consider the content of news in defining clickbaitiness of a headline; and we believe that such a network system would help social platforms to better integrate clickbait into a user experience problem.
